evt_desc: Tiziano Vecellio, known as Titian, was a leading Italian Renaissance painter, famous for his use of color and mastery in portraiture, religious, and mythological scenes. His works include Assumption of the Virgin and Venus of Urbino.

Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer, known as the “father of modern science.” He pioneered the use of telescopes, supported heliocentrism, and made key discoveries about planetary motion, inertia, and gravity. His works include Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems.

Vasco da Gama was a Portuguese explorer who pioneered the sea route from Europe to India, opening direct trade between the continents. His voyages around Africa’s Cape of Good Hope established Portugal’s dominance in global maritime trade during the Age of Exploration.

Ferdinand Magellan was a Portuguese explorer who led the first expedition to circumnavigate the globe. Though he was killed in the Philippines, his voyage proved the Earth’s roundness and expanded global trade routes, marking a major milestone in maritime exploration.

Johannes Vermeer was a Dutch Baroque painter known for his masterful use of light and color in domestic interior scenes. His works, like Girl with a Pearl Earring and The Milkmaid, capture everyday life with remarkable detail and tranquility.

El Greco, born Doménikos Theotokópoulos, was a Greek painter of the Spanish Renaissance known for his dramatic, elongated figures and expressive use of color. His works, like The Burial of the Count of Orgaz and View of Toledo, blend Byzantine and Western artistic traditions.

Diego Velázquez was a Spanish Baroque painter known for his realistic portraits and mastery of light. As court painter to King Philip IV, he created masterpieces like Las Meninas and The Surrender of Breda, influencing generations of artists with his technique.

Christopher Columbus was an Italian explorer who completed four voyages across the Atlantic, opening the Americas to European exploration. Sponsored by Spain, his 1492 voyage led to lasting contact between Europe and the New World, shaping global history.

Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn was a Dutch Baroque painter and printmaker, renowned for his realistic self-portraits and mastery of light and shadow. His works, such as The Night Watch and The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Tulp, are celebrated for their emotional depth and innovative techniques.
French philosopher and mathematician, known for "Cogito, ergo sum" and Cartesian geometry.
English mathematician and physicist, formulated laws of motion and universal gravitation.
Italian polymath of the High Renaissance, renowned for masterpieces like "Mona Lisa" and "The Last Supper".
Eldest son of King Edward III, renowned for his military leadership during the Hundred Years War.
Flemish painter active in Bruges, early innovator of Early Netherlandish painting, significant figure in Early Northern Renaissance art.
Spanish writer, author of Don Quixote, considered the first modern novel and a classic of Western literature.

Gian Lorenzo Bernini was an Italian sculptor, architect, and painter, widely regarded as the leading figure of Baroque art in the 17th century. He is known for masterpieces like the Ecstasy of Saint Teresa and the design of St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City.

Louis XIII, known as "le Juste", was King of France from 1610 to 1643. He strengthened royal authority with the help of Cardinal Richelieu, laying the foundation for absolute monarchy. His reign saw military victories and the centralization of power.

Charles V was Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain in the 16th century. He ruled a vast empire spanning Europe and the Americas, overseeing significant political and military conflicts, including wars against France and the Ottoman Empire.

The fall of Constantinople, also known as the conquest of Constantinople, was the capture of the capital of the Byzantine Empire by the Ottoman Empire. The city was captured on 29 May 1453 as part of the culmination of a 55-day siege which had begun on 6 April.

On October 12, 1492, Christopher Columbus, an Italian explorer sailing for Spain, landed in the Bahamas, believing he had reached Asia. His voyage marked the beginning of European exploration and colonization of the Americas, profoundly shaping world history.
Peter Paul Rubens was a Flemish Baroque painter renowned for his dynamic compositions of religious and mythological subjects. His vibrant style emphasized movement, color, and sensuality.
William the Conqueror, Duke of Normandy, became King of England after his victory at the Battle of Hastings in 1066. His reign marked significant changes in English governance and land ownership.

The Norman Conquest of England (1066) was led by William the Conqueror, culminating in the Battle of Hastings. It reshaped England’s monarchy, culture, and governance, introducing feudalism and Norman influence.

The Battle of Hastings took place on October 14, 1066, between the Norman-French army of William the Conqueror and the Anglo-Saxon forces of King Harold II. William's victory led to the Norman conquest of England.

The Hundred Years' War (1337–1453) was a series of conflicts between England and France over the French throne. It led to major political and military changes, including the rise of nationalism and the use of gunpowder in warfare.
The Battle of Poitiers (September 19, 1356) was a major battle in the Hundred Years' War, where English forces under the Black Prince decisively defeated the French, capturing King John II of France.
Joan of Arc was a French heroine and military leader during the Hundred Years' War. She played a key role in lifting the Siege of Orléans but was captured and executed for heresy at 19.
The Wars of the Roses were a series of English civil wars between the rival houses of Lancaster and York for control of the throne. The conflict ended with the rise of the Tudor dynasty.

The Thirty Years' War was a devastating conflict fought mainly in Central Europe, involving many European powers. It began as a religious war but evolved into a struggle for political dominance, ending with the Peace of Westphalia.
Richard I of England known as Richard the Lionheart, was King of England and a central figure in the Third Crusade. He was a skilled military leader but spent little time in England during his reign.

The First Crusade (1096–1099) was a military expedition by Western European Christians to recapture Jerusalem from Muslim rule. It resulted in the establishment of several Crusader states, including the Kingdom of Jerusalem.
The Second Crusade was launched in response to the fall of the County of Edessa to Muslim forces. It was led by European monarchs but ended in failure, weakening Crusader influence in the Holy Land.

The Third Crusade was launched to retake Jerusalem after its capture by Saladin. Led by Richard the Lionheart, Philip II of France, and Frederick Barbarossa, it achieved some victories but failed to reclaim the city.
The Fourth Crusade was intended to retake Jerusalem but was diverted. Instead, Crusaders sacked Constantinople, weakening the Byzantine Empire and deepening the Catholic-Orthodox schism.

Sandro Botticelli was an Italian painter of the Early Renaissance, known for masterpieces like The Birth of Venus and Primavera. His work blended classical themes with religious subjects, influencing Western art significantly.

Caravaggio was an Italian Baroque painter known for his dramatic use of light and shadow (chiaroscuro). His realistic and intense style influenced European art. Famous works include The Calling of Saint Matthew and Judith Beheading Holofernes.

Jheronimus Bosch was a Dutch painter of the Northern Renaissance, known for his surreal and fantastical imagery. His most famous work, The Garden of Earthly Delights, showcases his visionary style and moral themes.

Thomas Aquinas was an Italian Dominican friar and theologian, renowned for integrating Aristotelian philosophy with Christian doctrine. His seminal works, such as the 'Summa Theologica', have profoundly influenced Western thought.

The Black Death was a devastating global epidemic of bubonic plague that struck Europe and Asia between 1347 and 1351, killing millions. It profoundly shaped medieval society, economies, and religious attitudes.

Martin Luther was a German theologian and religious reformer who initiated the Protestant Reformation in the 16th century. His Ninety-five Theses challenged Catholic doctrines, leading to significant religious and political change in Europe.

Dante Alighieri was an Italian poet, writer, and philosopher, best known for his epic poem 'The Divine Comedy'. His work significantly influenced Italian literature and shaped the modern Italian language.

Geoffrey Chaucer was an English poet and author, best known for 'The Canterbury Tales'. He is considered the father of English literature and was instrumental in legitimizing the use of Middle English in written works.

Cesare Borgia was an Italian nobleman, politician, and military leader. A member of the powerful Borgia family, he was known for his ruthless tactics and served as inspiration for Machiavelli’s 'The Prince'.

Niccolò Machiavelli was an Italian Renaissance political philosopher, historian, and writer. He is best known for 'The Prince', a treatise on political power and statecraft, which influenced modern political theory.

Johannes Kepler was a German astronomer and mathematician who discovered the laws of planetary motion. His work laid the foundation for Newton's theory of gravitation and advanced the Scientific Revolution.

Thomas Jefferson was an American Founding Father, principal author of the Declaration of Independence, and the third U.S. president. He was a key advocate for democracy, individual rights, and the expansion of the young nation.

Giotto di Bondone was an Italian painter and architect from Florence during the Late Middle Ages. He is considered a pioneer in the transition from Byzantine to Renaissance art, known for his realistic depiction of human emotion and space.

Albrecht Dürer was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist from the Renaissance. He is best known for his woodcuts, engravings, and his significant contributions to the art of perspective and human proportions.

Oliver Cromwell was an English military and political leader best known for his role in the English Civil War and the subsequent establishment of the Commonwealth of England. He was Lord Protector from 1653 until his death in 1658.
Leonardo Fibonacci, also known as Leonardo of Pisa, was an Italian mathematician who introduced the Hindu-Arabic numeral system to Europe and is best known for the Fibonacci sequence.
Nicolaus Copernicus was a Polish astronomer who formulated a model of the universe that placed the Sun rather than the Earth at its center, known as the heliocentric theory.

Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath known for his contributions to science, politics, and diplomacy. He helped draft the Declaration of Independence and was an ambassador to France during the American Revolution.
Édouard Manet was a French painter pivotal to the transition from realism to impressionism. Known for his works such as 'Olympia' and 'Luncheon on the Grass', he challenged academic norms in art.
Francis of Assisi was an Italian friar and preacher who founded the Franciscan Order. He is known for his deep devotion to poverty, humility, and his love for nature and animals.
Petrarch was an Italian scholar, poet, and one of the earliest humanists. He is known for his poetry, particularly his sonnets dedicated to Laura, and his influence on the Renaissance.

Francis Bacon was an English philosopher, statesman, scientist, and author. He is known for developing the empirical method of scientific inquiry and for serving as Attorney General and Lord Chancellor of England.

George Washington was the first President of the United States, a Founding Father, and a leader in the American Revolutionary War. He is known for leading the Continental Army to victory over Great Britain.

Marco Polo was an Italian merchant, traveler, and pioneer who traveled extensively with his family, reaching China and influencing European understanding of Asian lands. His accounts of his travels are among the most famous works of the medieval period.

Thomas Hobbes was an English philosopher, best known for his book 'Leviathan', which established the foundation for most of Western political philosophy. He is also known for his social contract theory.
The American Revolution was a colonial revolt against Great Britain, resulting in the formation of the United States. It was fueled by Enlightenment ideals of liberty and the desire for independence.

James Joyce was an Irish modernist writer, best known for his groundbreaking works such as 'Ulysses' and 'A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,' which explored new narrative techniques and inner consciousness.
Rumi was a 13th-century Persian poet, theologian, and Sufi mystic. His spiritual and philosophical poetry has inspired millions worldwide.
Edward III was King of England from 1327 to 1377. His reign saw significant military victories, including the Battle of Crécy, and the start of the Hundred Years' War.
Peter the Great was the Tsar of Russia who transformed it into a major European power, known for his extensive reforms in government, culture, and military.
Ivan the Terrible was the first Tsar of Russia, known for his ruthless policies, including the mass executions during his reign, and his efforts to centralize power.
Marie Curie was a pioneering physicist and chemist, known for her discovery of radioactivity and winning two Nobel Prizes for her groundbreaking work.

Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino, known as Raphael, was an Italian painter and architect of the High Renaissance. Renowned for his Madonnas and large figure compositions, his work exemplifies the ideals of High Renaissance aesthetics. Notable works include 'The School of Athens' in the Vatican's Stanza della Segnatura.

Edgar Degas was a French artist famous for his paintings, sculptures, prints, and drawings. He is especially known for his works depicting dancers, capturing movement and grace with innovative compositions and lighting.

Antonio Vivaldi was an Italian Baroque composer, virtuoso violinist, and teacher. He is best known for his violin concertos, particularly 'The Four Seasons,' which vividly depict natural scenes through music.

Henry the Navigator was a Portuguese prince and key figure in the early days of the Age of Exploration. He supported maritime expeditions that expanded European knowledge of Africa and the Atlantic Ocean.

Nuestra Señora de la Santísima Trinidad, nicknamed La Real, was a Spanish first-rate ship of the line and was the largest warship in the world when launched.
The ship was launched in March 1769
evt_name: Nuestra Señora de la Santísima Trinidad

evt_desc: Sir Francis Drake was an English sea captain, privateer, navigator, and politician of the Elizabethan era. He was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe and played a key role in defeating the Spanish Armada.

Dutch humanist scholar, Catholic priest, and theologian, known for his critical and satirical writings. His works laid the foundation for religious reforms and the humanist movement in Northern Europe.
Michelangelo was an Italian Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect, and poet, renowned for masterpieces like the sculptures 'David' and the 'Pietà,' and the Sistine Chapel ceiling frescoes.

Amedeo Modigliani was an Italian painter and sculptor known for his portraits and nudes featuring elongated forms and unique facial expressions. His works were influenced by African masks and Renaissance art.

The Prague Astronomical Clock, installed in 1410, is one of the oldest and most famous astronomical clocks in the world. It features an intricate mechanism displaying astronomical details and hourly moving figures.

The Seven Years’ War was a global conflict involving major European powers, fought across Europe, the Americas, and Asia. It reshaped colonial empires and set the stage for future geopolitical shifts.

Donatello was an Italian sculptor of the Renaissance, known for his mastery of bronze and marble. His innovative techniques and lifelike sculptures, including David and Gattamelata, had a profound impact on Western art.

Hans Holbein the Younger was a German-Swiss painter and printmaker known for his detailed portraits and religious works. He became a court painter to Henry VIII of England and is recognized for his precise realism and mastery of oil painting.

Henry VIII was the King of England known for his six marriages and the English Reformation, which led to the Church of England breaking away from the Pope’s authority. His reign was marked by significant political and religious changes.

Mary I of England, known as 'Bloody Mary,' was the first queen to rule England in her own right. She is known for her attempt to restore Catholicism and her persecution of Protestants during her reign.

Elizabeth I was the last Tudor monarch of England, known for the Elizabethan era, the defeat of the Spanish Armada, and establishing Protestantism. Her reign was marked by cultural and economic growth.

William Shakespeare was an English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language. His works include timeless plays such as Hamlet, Macbeth, and Romeo and Juliet.

Avicenna was a Persian polymath and one of the most influential figures in medicine, philosophy, and science. His works, especially The Canon of Medicine, shaped medical knowledge in both the Islamic world and Europe.

Roger Bacon was an English philosopher and scientist who emphasized empirical methods and experimentation. He made contributions to optics, astronomy, and early scientific methodology in medieval Europe.

Lope de Vega was a Spanish playwright, poet, and novelist, one of the most prolific writers in literary history. He played a key role in the Spanish Golden Age and revolutionized Spanish theater with his dynamic and expressive plays.

Leonhard Euler was a Swiss mathematician and physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to calculus, graph theory, and number theory. His work significantly influenced modern mathematics and engineering.

The French Revolution was a period of social and political upheaval in France that led to the end of the monarchy, the rise of democracy, and widespread societal changes. It significantly influenced modern political ideologies.

Catherine the Great was the Empress of Russia who expanded the empire, modernized administration, and promoted Enlightenment ideals. Her reign saw significant cultural, political, and military advancements.
Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military leader and emperor who dominated European affairs. His legal and administrative reforms, including the Napoleonic Code, shaped modern governance and law.

David IV, known as David the Builder, was a medieval king who reigned from 1089 to 1125. He is celebrated for unifying Georgia, implementing significant military and cultural reforms, and establishing the Gelati Monastery as a major cultural center.

Tamar the Great was the first female monarch of Georgia, reigning from 1184 to 1213. Her rule is celebrated as the zenith of the Georgian Golden Age, marked by military victories and a flourishing of arts and culture.

On this day in 1602 the Dutch East India Company (VOC) was established. It possessed quasi-governmental powers, including the ability to wage war, negotiate treaties, strike its own coins and establish colonies. The VOC sent nearly a million Europeans to work in the Asia trade on 4,785 ships

Vladimir the Great, ruler of Kievan Rus' from 980 to 1015, played a pivotal role in the Christianization of Rus' in 988. Renowned for his military conquests and political reforms, he fostered cultural growth, strengthened trade, and established a centralized state, leaving a lasting legacy on Eastern Europe's history and religious landscape.

Yaroslav the Wise, Grand Prince of Kiev from 1019 to 1054, was a key figure in Kievan Rus' history. He expanded the state, codified laws in the Russkaya Pravda, promoted education, and fostered Byzantine cultural influence, solidifying Rus' as a major medieval power through diplomacy, architecture, and legal reforms.

Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch Post-Impressionist painter whose works are known for their bold colors and expressive brushwork. He created over 2,000 artworks, including famous paintings like The Starry Night and Sunflowers, influencing modern art.

Paul Gauguin was a French Post-Impressionist artist known for his bold colors, strong lines, and symbolic themes. He spent part of his life in Tahiti, creating unique artworks that influenced modern art movements like Primitivism and Expressionism.
